questions.questiontext: Which gear is most often best to approach roundabouts in?
questions.answertext: 2nd gear allows you to make good progress if the way is clear. Stop and select 1st if not.

questions.questiontext: Where should you be looking as you approach a roundabout?
questions.answertext: Right and all around. It's important to look right for traffic you may need to stop for, left to see where you must steer and all around the roundabout to register all traffic and anticipate opportunity.
Left lane no signal on approach -Left signal at 'b'

choices.text: Left lane left signal on approach -Left signal at 'b'
Right lane no signal on approach-Left signal at'b'
Left lane no signal on approach -Left signal at 'b'
Left lane no signal on approach -Left signal at 'c'

questions.answertext: Right lane right signal on approach - Left signal at 'd'

choices.text: Right lane no signal on approach -Left signal at 'd'
Right lane right signal on approach -Left signal at 'e'
Left lane right signal on approach -Left signal at 'd'
Right lane right signal on approach - Left signal at 'd'

questions.answertext: Right lane right signal on approach -Left signal at 'e'

choices.text: Left lane right signal on approach -Left signal at 'e'
Right lane no signal on approach -Left signal at 'e'
Right lane right signal on approach -Left signal at 'e'
Right Lane right signal on approach - Left signal at 'd'

questions.questiontext: What do you not need to do at a mini roundabout?
questions.answertext: You don't need an exit signal. This is because the small size of the roundabout can require a lot of steering.It's not a mistake to signal but it could cause a steering error.
